FK.content: etymology never provides a law, only material for thinking
FK.linkedContent: etymology never provides a law, only material for thinking

SPOM.content: [re: Marx “deconstructing” Stirner] Derrida notes theme of food, Last Supper, host as conjuring tricks naively accrediting discursive powers: “abuse of etymology that serves as explanation, play on homonyms, privileging of nomination, autonomization of language”
SPOM.linkedContent: [re: Marx “deconstructing” Stirner] Derrida notes theme of food, Last Supper, host as conjuring tricks naively accrediting discursive powers: “abuse of etymology that serves as explanation, play on homonyms, privileging of nomination, autonomization of language”

OOG.content: Heidegger’s etymologies determine rather than follow (Husserl) orientation of investigation
OOG.linkedContent: Heidegger’s etymologies determine rather than follow (Husserl) orientation of investigation

S.content: war of etymology [re: Geist], the ghosts flapping in what Artaud would call this “alchemical theater”
S.linkedContent: war of etymology [re: Geist], the ghosts flapping in what Artaud would call this “alchemical theater”

WM.content: classical motif, etymon of a primitive sense always determinable, interprets degradation as passage from physical to metaphysical > [valuing sensory image as “original figure,” against the concept, is its own conceptualization]
WM.linkedContent: classical motif, etymon of a primitive sense always determinable, interprets degradation as passage from physical to metaphysical > [valuing sensory image as “original figure,” against the concept, is its own conceptualization]

WM.content: Marx against etymologism (like Rousseau, Leibniz, Plato), rails against Stirner, who refutes communist abolition of property via etymology: essential “having” in Eigentum (property)
WM.linkedContent: Marx against etymologism (like Rousseau, Leibniz, Plato), rails against Stirner, who refutes communist abolition of property via etymology: essential “having” in Eigentum (property)

DS.content: etymology used to maintain, conserve > i.e. the surgeon who asked Freud, “how can a man be hysterical if Hysteron signifies ‘uterus’?”
DS.linkedContent: etymology used to maintain, conserve > i.e. the surgeon who asked Freud, “how can a man be hysterical if Hysteron signifies ‘uterus’?”

POS.content: WM systematizes critique of etymologism in philosophy and rhetoric
POS.linkedContent: WM systematizes critique of etymologism in philosophy and rhetoric

P.content: for Hegel, art has a single meaning, une vérité une et nue, an etymon, that can be unveiled through history > wouldn’t this mean art is outside of history? but philosophers have always been too quick to deem art historical via opposition tekhnē/physis translated as art/nature
P.linkedContent: for Hegel, art has a single meaning, une vérité une et nue, an etymon, that can be unveiled through history > wouldn’t this mean art is outside of history? but philosophers have always been too quick to deem art historical via opposition tekhnē/physis translated as art/nature

POOF.content: after quoting Benveniste, who says it is time to “begin to see what it [phílos] signifies,” Derrida says: “indeed (voire)” [i.e. would etymology be that beginning?]
POOF.linkedContent: after quoting Benveniste, who says it is time to “begin to see what it [phílos] signifies,” Derrida says: “indeed (voire)” [i.e. would etymology be that beginning?]

ROP.content: history of uses of a word [re: Foucault] is neither essentialist nor nominalist, it is a history of problematizations, to analyze all problematic intersections also calls for problematization of its own problematization > avec sa vigilance réflexive et le souci de se penser dans sa rigoureuse spécificité > which must itself question itself w/ same care that it methodically prescribes
ROP.linkedContent: history of uses of a word [re: Foucault] is neither essentialist nor nominalist, it is a history of problematizations, to analyze all problematic intersections also calls for problematization of its own problematization > avec sa vigilance réflexive et le souci de se penser dans sa rigoureuse spécificité > which must itself question itself w/ same care that it methodically prescribes

SP.content: Derrida quotes an accusation that he uses Littré for the sanctity of definition, as a bourgeois fixation
SP.linkedContent: Derrida quotes an accusation that he uses Littré for the sanctity of definition, as a bourgeois fixation

DST.content: Lacoue-Labarthe: Heidegger draws stehen and stellen together by identifying stal of stellein (to equip, to send word for) w/ sta of stele (column), he also links thesis via dhe to Setzung, Stellung, Lage—more philological Witz than true etymologism
DST.linkedContent: Lacoue-Labarthe: Heidegger draws stehen and stellen together by identifying stal of stellein (to equip, to send word for) w/ sta of stele (column), he also links thesis via dhe to Setzung, Stellung, Lage—more philological Witz than true etymologism

HST.content: Derrida tells this story: he was thinking of substitution, he thought of the example of stealing a child, replacing it w/ another, then he went to Littré (as a matter of duty, to verify, to search for an example), and the first definition/example is child substitution [mes chances]
HST.linkedContent: Derrida tells this story: he was thinking of substitution, he thought of the example of stealing a child, replacing it w/ another, then he went to Littré (as a matter of duty, to verify, to search for an example), and the first definition/example is child substitution [mes chances]

LI.content: etymology has no value as proof: if Sanskrit itara does not mean alterity, etymology’s mistake confirms law of iterability
LI.linkedContent: etymology has no value as proof: if Sanskrit itara does not mean alterity, etymology’s mistake confirms law of iterability
